metadata.sermon_start_end: Let us think, just for a passing moment, of the most sinful thing we have ever done. Think now of the most sinful thing you have ever seen. Think now of the most sinful thing of which you have ever heard. Recently a family in another state [...] All hail the power of Jesus' Name Let angels prostrate fall, Bring forth the royal diadem And crown Him Lord of all.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon identifies a specific pericope but fails to extract what is unique to this text. It quickly moves into generalities about sin and the atonement that could be derived from any Passion narrative. The 'nowhere else' quality of the crown of thorns is treated as a springboard for general moralizing on humor rather than a specific revelation.
quotes: In becoming this awful thing we call sin... our Lord encountered many things, some of which we are looking at on the road to Calvary.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus specifically on the irony of the 'mock coronation' in Matthew's theology—why this specific mockery of kingship is necessary for the reader to understand God's sovereignty.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher relies on secondary sources (Dr. James Stalker) and general historical knowledge of Roman scourging rather than primary exegetical work. There is no evidence of engagement with the original Greek or the specific theological structure of Matthew's Gospel.
quotes: Dr. James Stalker tells us: 'The victim was stripped and stretched against a pillar...'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Analyze the specific Greek terms for the 'scarlet robe' or the 'reed' to uncover the precise nature of the Roman mockery in its first-century context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding social behaviors (humor, church 'fixing', family grudges), which aligns with Dekker's demand for specificity. However, it occasionally veers into moralism rather than theological application of the text.
quotes: Put a false date on the marriage license; falsify to the government what one gave the church...
I know of nothing more vulgar and repulsive than fools who show their coarseness... by crude, filthy humor.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the contemporary 'mockery of the holy' more directly to the text's depiction of Christ's kingship rather than just a critique of bad manners.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'block' structure: an anecdote, then a theological reflection on sin, then a historical description, then a moral lesson on humor. The hearer is not consistently 'drawn into the text' as a single movement of revelation.
quotes: I would pause to say that we may take lesson here as to an awful danger. Humor is a great and marvelous gift.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid 'pausing' to give lessons; let the exposition of the Roman barracks naturally reveal the contemporary 'barracks' of our own hearts.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes misery (sin as 'rotting corruption') and redemption (Christ becoming sin). The psychological aspect is present, as Dekker suggests, by asking the hearer to visualize their own sin.
quotes: Christ in love became for us the smell of rotting corruption, which is what sin is.
He changed and changes curses to prayers. He changes hurt to healing.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' part is more than a hymn quote; show how the specific text enables a specific form of thankful living.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. While sin is described as loathsome, the actual consequence of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is not presented as a serious choice for the hearer. It remains somewhat descriptive rather than confrontational.
quotes: A people, a nation that holds nothing so sacred... is a society in trouble.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher should address the hearer's own participation in the mockery and the ultimate consequence of rejecting Christ's kingship.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon moves toward the exaltation of the Lamb. It maintains the two-natures doctrine implicitly by emphasizing the 'divine Son of God' suffering physical and psychic pain.
quotes: The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ.
He changed the crown of thorns to that crown of life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Deepen the grace aspect by showing how the crown of thorns specifically—not just the crucifixion in general—is the source of our life.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1650 words, the sermon likely lasts 16-17 minutes. According to Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and theological middle section to reach the 20-minute threshold, allowing the text to breathe.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's standards primarily in its brevity and its tendency to use the biblical text as a thematic anchor for general moral reflections rather than a unique source of revelation. While it captures the 'misery' and 'redemption' aspects of the 3-2-1 rule effectively, it lacks the rigorous exegetical depth (Greek/Hebrew context) and the 'two ways' confrontation required for a complete sermon.
strengths: Strong psychological engagement with the concept of sin and misery.
Clear Christocentric focus, moving toward the exaltation of Christ as King.
Concrete contemporary examples of ethical failures (application).
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (under 20 minutes) to achieve necessary depth.
Lack of specific exegesis of the Matthean text's unique nuances.
Absence of the 'two ways'—the seriousness of being lost is not sharply presented.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate homiletical address, but it is not a 'sermon' in the full sense of Dekker's definition. It lacks the necessary breadth of exposition and the sharp, specific 'nowhere else' insight that characterizes the actualization of the Word.
